rename.from: `Table::save()` should return false if transaction gets rolledback in `afterSave()` callback
rename.to: Table::save() should return false if transaction gets rolled back in afterSave() callback

body:
Isn't `afterSave` now implemented with events. As a result, there could be many listeners responding to `afterSave`. As far as I'm aware, there is no way for a listener to signal that the event is a failure. You can only signal the stopping of propagation.

I would recommend an exception be thrown that is caught by the `Table::save()` when it broadcasts the afterSave. That would be easier and more stable than trying to handle a response true/false from multiple listeners. 

Developers would have to throw this exception from afterSave to signal a failure.
I agree with @thinkingmedia. Your failing `afterSave` should throw an exception, that will abort the transaction from what I can see.

The failed save in afterSave() already rolls back the transaction and the changes done in primary save are also lost. Hence the primary save should return false without having to throw an exception.

This issue was encountered by "crazycoder" on IRC and it took quite a while to figure out why changes were not being persisted to db in spite of save() returning an entity.

This has not much to do with the return value of afterSave. The issue is executing a failing transaction in the afterSave callback will rollback all of the operation.

`save()` should detect that the transaction was rolled back and maybe throw an exception there, or just return false.... But I'm leaning more towards an exception
@thinkingmedia The save in `afterSave()` failed due to validation / application rules not SQL error in which case there wouldn't be any exception.
@ADmad why would validation / rules trigger a rollback?

Cause that's how Table::save() works :) This is necessary as one might be trying to save an entity with associated entities, so if one of the associated entities fails validation/rules the transaction is rolled back to revert any changes to primary record too to ensure atomic operation.

But that's not the same thing. Associated data is saved as part of the `save()` process, and I think that process is working fine. `afterSave` is an event after that process has finished. If the developer is doing something at that stage and needs to abort the `save()` operation, then the code should throw an exception.

If a developer needs to stop a `save()` because of validations / rules executed in a listener. The developer should be using the `beforeSave` event. Which allows you to stop the save operation.

Keep in mind, that the `afterSave` event is broadcasted to all listeners. If one listener rolls back changes and invalidates the save operation, then this will produce bugs in the other listeners that were executed first, because those listeners assumed the save operation was successful and that's why they are responsing to the `afterSave` event

As far as `save()` is concerned when it broadcasts `afterSave` it's responsibilities are done. That is the purpose of that event.

I'm still confused on how a listener can roll back a transaction that it did not start. Each `save()` call uses `transactional` which would create a nested transaction. 

If the developer needs to execute business logic (validation or rules) on multiple tables. They should be saving each entity individually inside a `transactional` and manage that process themselves. 

Again, I think we need to see code that demonstrates the issue as we're now getting into a debate about the problem, and there is nothing productive about that.

Can anyone write a quick unit test that reproduces the issue? Even just a quick hack as an example, it doesn't have to actually work.
